title: ReThink: Is the Bible Trustworthy?
description:
In this summer of chaos, many of us are rethinking our life’s key assumptions. In this series called Rethink - we are asking the questions that matter. If you’re just joining in - check out the other questions we've looked at so far!

One correction to the video (by Denis) - I say that there are about 750 prophecies in the Bible and 600 have already come true - about 80%. Then I say the Bible is batting .800 which is wrong! The Bible is batting 1.000 so far, with 20% of at-bats yet to happen. My apologies!

title: Lament and Protest as Worship
description:
Lament is a Biblical act of Worship to God. A great example of an individual lament is Psalm 13.

Biblical Lament has 5 Elements:
1. Introductory Cry to God
2. Lament - expressing the complaint
3. Petition - specifically asking God to do something
4. Statement of Confidence in God's character
5. Vow to Praise God

How do we apply this today?
1. When you are angry, frustrated, hurting, anxious, etc. - go to your Father in Heaven!
2. Be honest with the way you feel - it's okay to scream!
3. Be specific about what you are asking God to do about this situation
4. Remind yourself that the Father is good and trustworthy
5. Praise Him even in the midst of suffering; look forward to perfect justice coming in the New Heaven and the New Earth (Revelation 21:1-4)

title: Wednesday Devotional: How to focus on God among the chaos of life
description: Anna Moderwell talks about how worship might look different when everyday life is so crazy. It is difficult to focus on God and worship and you just need God to meet you right where you are.

title: A Biblical Perspective on our Unrest
description:
Denis shares his heart on the unrest around us in a three part devotional:

1. The Father is revealing sin and wickedness against those made in his image
We all witness the shocking taking of a human life
We see protests with a large majority of young white people
Those dropping pallets of bricks seek to discredit the protest by inciting violence

2. This is a Gospel and discipleship issue - looking at Jesus' example in John 4
Jesus - one of the majority takes the first step
Jesus reveals the woman's sin
She changes the subject to wrong ideas of worship
He corrects her and reveals he is her messiah
She runs into town and the harvest of Samaritans comes to fruition
Jesus overturns 700 years of racial enmity in two days - Gospel power
WE NEED CHANGE  - AND ONLY THE GOSPEL WILL DO!

3. Providing practical biblical next steps for us to continue our journey.
We must be committed to righteousness AND justice (Isaiah 9:7, Psalms 103:6)
Jesus told the Pharisees that they missed the weightier matters of justice (Matt 23:23)
Speaking out is not useless - Job, Ezekiel and Jesus on the yeast of the Pharisees
Prayer - persevering prayer for justice is what Jesus taught (Luke 18:1-8)
Come pray with us Wednesday nights from 7-8 on the front porch socially distanced
Listen and empathize (James 1:19, John 13:34-35, Romans 12:15, Galatians 6:1-10)
Way of love (Ephesians 5:1-2)

1. Google the story of Emmett Till

2. Books to read:
The Cross and the Lynching Tree, by James Cone
Divided by Faith, by Michael Emerson
Color of Compromise, by Jemar Tisby
One Blood, by John Perkins
The New Jim Crow, by Michelle Alexander

3. Videos to watch
13th on Netflix
Maafa 21 - on youtube
Just Mercy - showing free this month

4. Attend some gatherings:
Pray with New Mission at 4807 Ravenna Street June 13 from 330-430 pm
Join Second Sundays Zoom call June 14 at 700 pm 
Email mariel.beausejour@gmail.com for the Zoom link
Watch for Tracy Ventus' video message to us (at my request) next week

title: What are Spiritual Gifts? How Do I Use Them?
description:
Jamie shares 6 observations about Spiritual Gifts from 1 Peter 4:10-11:
1. Every believer is "gifted" (v10a)
2. Gifts are for loving service of others (v10b)
3. There is a diversity of giftedness (v10c)
4. Gifts can be neglected (v10c)
5. Gifts can be categorized by supernatural: a) speaking; or b) serving (v11a)
6. Gifts point others to the Father and the Son (v11b)

Practical Suggestions (if you don't know what your gifts are, or how to use them):
1. Ask the Spirit for the mind and heart of Jesus for those around you
2. Open your eyes to those around you and be present (put the phone down)
3. Ask the Father to manifest His Grace and Presence to the person in front of you
4. Begin to either speak words of encouragement (as you feel led), OR physically serve the person in some way - just start doing something that is loving! (speaking or serving)
5. Pray and ask for more gifts (1 Cor 14:1, "earnestly desire . . .")

title: Confession of Sin: 3 Practical Tips
description:
Three Practical Tips:

First: Be Quick to Confess Sin; unconfessed sin has physical and spiritual consequences (Psalm 32:1-5; Psalm 81:11-12)

Second: Ask for spiritual eyes to see the glory of God (Isaiah 6:1-8)

Third: Having confessed your sin to God, walk under grace, not under law (Luke 15:17-24)

title: Wednesday Devo - Marianne on Confession
description:
Marianne discusses three major areas where confession seems to be most challenging as we follow Jesus: pride, unbelief, and idolatry.

Marianne also gives a great encouragement for walking in God's power in temptation and being more victorious.

title: Denis - Tuesday Devo - Confession
description:
In this devotional Denis shares a "spring cleaning" type of "re-set" confession.

He uses a challenging Sin Inventory developed by Charles Finney (1792-1875) who was an American Presbyterian minister and a key leader in the Second Great Awakening (1800-1820). (Thanks to Mariel and Steven Manuel for sharing this tool.)

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1WTWNuSPDEXhuFLts6VGEgqo-13Gt6Qp7tGa85jmMe_0/edit

David gives a great witness to confession in Psalm 32:1-5

Confession is always challenging because we tend to minimize our sin. 
It is crucial to seek the scrutiny of God - Psalm 139:23-24
We need people around us who know our weaknesses and are willing to speak truth.

Denis encourages us to examine our sins of omission and commission. 

You will feel light and free and close to the Lord when you agree with him on what isn’t right in your life and turn from it.

May the Lord wash you squeaky clean! Denis

title: Denis Tuesday Devo - Life-Altering Bible Reading
description:
In this video Denis shares 5 of his personal lessons that will help your reading and study of the Scriptures result in life-altering transformation.

1. Come to the Bible hungry.
2. Read and study with the intent to obey.
3. Expect to be transformed.
4. Read it as one story, with one author, and one hero!
5. Ask God to write you into his story and play your part with all you've got.

title: Happy Star Wars Day (May the 4th)! The Greatest Story Ever!
description:
Happy Star Wars Day! (May the 4th Be With You!)

The Great Story of Scripture has 7 Acts (below is taken from Christopher J. H. Wright):
Act 1: Creation. The whole drama begins when the one living and eternal God chooses to create what we call the universe—heaven and earth. He creates it “good,” and he creates human beings in God’s own image, to rule and serve his good creation.
Act 2: Rebellion. Humans choose to distrust God’s goodness, disbelieve God’s word, and disobey God’s instructions. As a result, sin and evil enter into every dimension of human life, personal and social, and also corrupt all cultures and bring damage and frustration to creation.
Act 3: Promise. The story of the rest of the Old Testament begins with God’s promise to Abraham that not only will he become a great nation (Israel), but also that through them God will bring blessing to all nations on earth. That promise and hope drives the story forward through the history of Israel in the Old Testament era, as we shall survey.
Act 4: Gospel. The promise of the Old Testament comes to fulfillment when Jesus of Nazareth is born. The great central act of the drama of Scripture includes all that we read in the four Gospels: the conception, birth, life, teaching, atoning death, victorious resurrection, and ascension of Messiah Jesus.
Act 5: Mission. The promise to Abraham must be fulfilled. The good news of what God has accomplished through his Son Jesus must go to all nations. This is launched at the end of the Gospels and the beginning of Acts, after the outpouring of the Spirit of God on the followers of Jesus.
Act 6: Final judgment. The good news is that evil will not have the last word and God will ultimately put all things right (which is what judgment means in the Bible) by dealing with and destroying all that is wrong and evil. Act 6 is the completion of God’s answer to act 2 and of the accomplishment of act 4.
Act 7: New creation. The Bible drama ends with a dramatic new beginning! After putting all things right, God will make all things new and will come to dwell with redeemed humanity in his restored creation forever.

Christopher J. H. Wright, The Old Testament in Seven Sentences: A Small Introduction to a Vast Topic (Downers Grove, IL: IVP Academic: An Imprint of InterVarsity Press, 2019), 4–6.

Join Jamie for 30 Days of Bible reading (1-2 chapters a day). "The Bible's Story in 30 Days" - link is here: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1lTecslB7w1_F3sKSgv4maNCTY8xtgQ09/view?usp=sharing 

Other Suggested Bible Resources:
• A good readable translation of the Bible (NIV, NASB, ESV, NKJV, NLT)
• A good Study Bible (Faithlife Study Bible is free online with an email account - https://faithlife.com/products/faithlife-study-bible)  
• A good Bible Dictionary (Faithlife Study Bible comes with the Lexham Bible Dictionary for free!)

Recommended Books to Assist in Bible Study:
• Fee, Gordon D., and Douglas K. Stuart. How to Read the Bible for All Its Worth. 3rd ed. Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan Publishing House, 1993.
• Guthrie, George H. Read the Bible for Life. Nashville, TN: B&H Books, 2011.
• Hendricks, Howard G., and William D. Hendricks. Living by the Book: The Art and Science of Reading the Bible. Chicago: Moody Publishers, 2007.
• Warren, Rick. Rick Warren’s Bible Study Methods: Twelve Ways You Can Unlock God's Word. Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan, 2006.

title: Thursday Devotional: “God Reveals Our Creativity”
description:
Today I wanted to share with you a poem I wrote recently. The reason I am sharing with you is that in my writing process I try to invite God into my creative space. While I don’t do this every time, when I do, I can feel Him guiding my thoughts and my pen. I look at creativity in the 3 parts, practice, discipline, and invitation, more on that in the video!

I have recently been inspired by the imagery in the Psalms, in particular, Psalm 36:5-10 (ESV).               I believe there is creativity in all of us, though this looks different in each person because we were made in the Creator’s image. We just need to invite His presence into our project and let him flow through us. I challenge you to invite Him into your next project, I think you might just be surprised! I hope you enjoy the poem.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1aD3UoKf9uLyjSCNwQEQVi_1UGq2yysep9BrGQk06TTA/edit

title: Holy Reading: Fellowship of the Burning Heart
description:
An important Spiritual Practice (not necessarily a "discipline" of Jesus) is Holy Reading. This is the practice of exposing ourselves to books from men and women who were "on fire" with passion for Jesus and His Kingdom! When our hearts get cold, we can warm them with these authors, who represent the "Fellowship of the Burning Heart."

Recommended Reading:
A. W. Tozer (anything really), "The Pursuit of God"
Francois Fenelon, "Christian Counsel"
Brother Lawrence, "The Practice of the Presence of God"
Richard Foster, "Celebration of Discipline"
Dallas Willard, "The Spirit of the Disciplines"
Donald Whitney, "Spiritual Disciplines for the Christian Life"
"The Autobiography of George Mueller"

title: April 21 - Tuesday Devotional : Rhythms of Jesus
description: Denis shares a bit of his personal journey with the spiritual disciplines we will practice together over the next 8 weeks. Coming from Luke 14:25-35 Denis emphasizes that the cost of true discipleship to Jesus is significant and it is a journey that cannot be undertaken without the love of the Father, the grace of Jesus, and the power of the Spirit. Said another way, Following Jesus is impossible on our own power! Spiritual disciplines are therefore not a checklist of "to-do's" but rather means of grace that enable us to be transformed into the likeness of Jesus. They are opportunities to grow and become more like Jesus. So let's embark on this adventure together and ask God to lead us to greater maturity.

title: Follow Me: The Rhythms of Jesus
description:
4/19/20 – “Follow Me: The Rhythms of Jesus” (Luke 6:12-19; Acts 2:42-47)

Document with Scriptures and Worship Lyrics https://docs.google.com/document/d/1870g9mZOJSIp8mLEE44HBlfGDZZ0667FHD8Ahz3aPlw/edit?ts=5e87d26b

Following Jesus is:
Relational (Luke 6:12-19; Acts 2:42-47)
Intentional (Luke 6:13-16; Acts 2:42, 46)
Missional (Luke 6:17-19; Acts 2:43-47)
Reproducible (Matt 28:18-20; Acts 2:47)

Order of Disciplines Coming Up in the Series:
Prayer and Practicing the Presence of God (Apr 26)
Scripture Reading and Study (May 3)
Silence, Solitude, and Hearing from God (May 10)
Confession of Sin (May 17)
Feasting and Fasting (May 24)
Giving, Serving and Sharing Good News (Pentecost May 31 – effects of HS)
Worship (June 7)
Sabbath Rest (June 14)

Application Question:
Are you committed to following and becoming like Jesus, or just learning about Him?

Action Steps:
1) Read through the list of disciplines, and comment below about which you are most interested in learning.
2) Read Luke 6:12-19 and Acts 1-2 this week; ask yourself “based on these texts, how should my life and our church look differently when we come out of isolation? What can I do now to follow Jesus more closely?”

title: Follow Me
description:
Is it possible that this virus is being used by the Father to force the Church to do a reboot, or a factory reset? Is it possible that we have a chance to reset our rhythms and patterns as individuals and a church family? What does that look like, practically?
Jamie tells us about our new sermon series that starts this Sunday!

title: Tuesday Devotional - What's Next?
description: Denis looks at Acts 1:1-11 and outlines four things for us to lay hold of in this transitional season between Resurrection Sunday and Pentecost Sunday. These four things are: 1) Kingdom instruction; 2) Intimacy with Jesus; 3) Receiving Holy Spirit; and 4) our mission to a broken world.

title: Holy Week: Good Friday Devotional
description:
3 Scenes from Good Friday (Matthew 27:1-66):
The Trial of Jesus (Mt 27:11-26)
The Crucifixion of Jesus (Mt 27:27-50)
The Death of Jesus (Mt 27:50-61)

Have you put your trust in Jesus as Savior and Lord of your life? Trust Him. He was crucified for your sin and brokenness. Receive His grace today.

Check out the song, "How Deep the Father's Love for Us" by Stuart Townsend, and give thanks today for the sacrifice of Jesus on your behalf.

Don't neglect His Presence. The Veil is torn in two. Practice His Presence today.

Much love,
Jamie

title: Holy Week - Thursday Devotional
description: Denis looks at the powerfully humble love of Jesus in John 13:1-17 - an object lesson helping us understand what Jesus means in verses 34-35 - his new command to love one another. Jesus raises the bar on love - we are to love sacrificially the way Jesus loved us! Denis also gives some background about the Essenes sect of Judaism and the Upper Room, which has been located in the Essene Quarter of the City. He also identifies the hymn that Jesus and the disciples sang before leaving for the garden of Gethsemane - most likely Psalms 113-117. Enjoy "Maundy" Thursday - from the Latin "Novum Mandatum" meaning New Command. In many respects, Jesus is inaugurating a new world order!

title: Holy Week: Wednesday Devotional
description:
What is Jesus worth? 

We see two responses to that question in the text today. Matthew 26:6-16 tells the story of the woman who anoints Jesus at Bethany, and Judas who accepts a bribe to betray Jesus. To one, Jesus is worth giving up a year's salary; to the other, Jesus is worth betraying for 30 pieces of silver. How about you? What is Jesus worth to you?

After you watch this, 
look up "Is He Worthy?" 
by Andrew Peterson. https://youtu.be/6FEuAr8f6bo
Ask the Holy Spirit to show you the glory of Jesus, and then watch the video. 

Much love to you, Jamie

title: Holy Week: Tuesday Devotional
description: Denis walks us through Matthew's account of the Holy Week from 21:18 through to 22:46 as Jesus demonstrates his supreme authority in a set of teachings ranging from a withered fig tree near the Mount of Olives and a series of teachings on the Temple Mount. You will be encouraged deeper in discipleship - in your prayer life and the way you handle doubts.

title: Holy Week: Monday Devotional
description: On Monday of Holy Week, Jesus cleanses the Temple! Mark 11:15-19

title: Lord's Supper Reminder and Brief Teaching
description:
Quick reminder that we are celebrating Communion this Sunday (4/5 - Palm Sunday). Work ahead to have your juice and bread read to go before the 10am start time. Also, if you are isolating by yourself with no one else in the home, consider FaceTiming a fellow MCC'er during the Lord's Supper and take it together.

Here's a brief teaching. The Lord's Supper is: 
1) a covenant meal celebrating forgiveness of sins (Mt 26:26-28)
2) participation and fellowship with Christ (1 Cor 10:16)
3) an act of thanksgiving, remembrance, and proclamation (1 Cor 11:24-26)
4) a community act of fellowship with one another (Acts 2:42-47) 
5) an anticipatory act of longing for eternity (Mt 26:29)
Hey All, Thanks for joining me in worship this morning. Papa is so good!

title: Where is God in this Plague?
description:
This is a brief run down of what the Scriptures say about God's purposes in plagues. I share 5 purposes and 4 application questions that I hope will encourage you.

Also, I developed a Discovery Bible Study you may want to do as a family or share with your friends, extended family, neighbors or co-workers. You can find it here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1r5bYfZMegXaoxijlTz83TU30milBKmgM/edit

title: What is Jesus' perspective on COVID-19?
description:
What is Jesus’ perspective on COVID-19?
Looking at Luke 8:22-26, we learn 5 things about Jesus and His perspective on storms in our lives:

1) Jesus is Never Stressed (v22-23)
2) Jesus Saves! (v24)
3) Yielded-ness to Jesus Brings Calm (v24)
4) Every Circumstance in Life is a Learning Opportunity about Jesus (v25)
5) Jesus Intentionally Leads His Disciples out of their Comfort Zone for Mission (v22, 26)

title: How to be at PEACE during social isolation.
description:
If we want to be at PEACE, we need to follow the rhythms of Jesus, the Prince of Peace. He practiced the rhythms of UP (intimacy with the Father), IN (growing with spiritual family/disciples), and OUT (intentional Kingdom engagement with those outside of faith).

Practical steps:
UP: 1) take time for Bible Reading and Prayer everyday; 2) wash your hands for 20 seconds praying "The Lord's Prayer"; 3) Jump on FB live worship with Raz and others; 4) set your alarm for every 30 minutes - pray thanksgiving when the alarm goes off
IN: 1) join with MCC family during prayer meeting zooms (Tue Noon, Wed 7:30pm, Thu 7:00am); 2) stay connected with Zoom small groups; 3) intentionally call,  text, FaceTime church family to check in and engage; 4) get some work done around the house or in the yard
OUT: 1) take a walk outside; 2) prayer-walk your neighborhood; 3) place a note on your neighbor's door with your name and contact info, offering to pray, assist, pick up groceries, etc. be a good neighbor; 4) download and engage with the "Next Door App"; 5) signup on "BlessEveryHome.com" with your address and link up with Mariemont Church.

When  you are stressed, go UP and ask the Father how you can engage IN or OUT.

Check out the church website for details on upcoming Zoom meetings, FB Worship, and devos . . .

www.mariemontchurch.org

Much love, Jamie

title: 3-15-20 Sunday Sermon
description: Due to the Covid-19 situation, join us, the church which is not a building but the people who accept Jesus Christ as Savior in worshipping and fellowshipping together online.

Hey everyone, as part of our journey of racial reconciliation in the Body of Christ, we are supporting the Race to Unity Rally on July 28 (7-9 PM) and July 29 (9:30 AM-1PM, lunch provided) at People's Church. Address is 220 Wm. Howard Taft. Great speakers, will build your understanding and conviction. RSVP unity@racetounity.com. This is all leading to the 2018 Conference September 14-15. See video from Louis Arnold and me. Please pray!

A few years ago we felt led to move our VBS to the Bright Star summer camp down on the West End. It's blessed us more than we ever imagined. Thank you to the Swann's who have really stood firm on the vision! ❤️
Something about men praying and worshipping Jesus together!

Beautiful worship as leaders from 6 tribes in north west Nigeria give praise. It's a powerful testimony to Jesus as those that formerly hated one another now love. Keep praying that they would bring the Gospel in love and unity to the more than 3 million people they represent!
Something special about men united to worship Jesus together! 🎯
A brief word of encouragement from Corinth! We ❤️ you! D&M
Team Worship at the Garden Tomb!!!
Terri reciting her Scripture memory from Matthew 14, on our boat on the Sea of Galilee with the disciples!
Early morning worship on Sea of Galilee - what a great God we have!
Part of our team worship at Beth Shan, in the ancient Roman Theater! Having a wonderful time together with Father Son and Spirit!

Worship in the ancient olive grove at Mount Carmel - celebrating God grafting us into the eternal olive tree as we ask for the fire of God to shape our lives in the way the Spirit shaped Elijah. Keep your prayers coming for our team, we are growing closer every day!
A brief greeting from Tel Aviv. Team doing well! Keep praying!
